speaker: Mr Johnson (Ryan) (11.10 A.m.)
theText: It gives me pleasure to say a few words in this com5552 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 August 2002 One of the most important things for our country is small business because it is the small businesses of our country that employ people and give the local communities and local suburbs throughout the country community support. I think that it is imperative that all governments at all levels, in particular the federal government, give full support and full weight to all that small and medium sized businesses do in our country. I know that this government, the Howard government, certainly does that and it is a great pleasure to be involved in supporting that as a junior member of the parliament and the federal member for Ryan. As I said, we had the pleasure of the workplace relations minister coming to launch the small business advisory committee, and he had the opportunity of meeting some of the members of that committee. I want to mention a few of those members, the backgrounds that they come from and the sorts of small businesses they have, because these people-the Australians in small business-are the people who are at the coalface, who are at the grass roots base of small business. They and their experiences will help all governments of whatever persuasion and at whatever tier in our system of government to develop good ideas, good outcomes and good policies. The workplace relations minister was certainly very enthusiastic and very supportive of this initiative. One member of the committee, Mr Tony Everett, is from The Gap and he has a business that has two employees. He established his business about 10 years ago, with his wife, and it is called the Safe-T School of Motoring. What he does is teach young people how to drive. This might seem to be an innocuous business but it is very important because he is imparting good habits to and good skills amongst the young people of our community who are beginning their driving lessons. Before he began his own small business, he had many other backgrounds and areas of interest and expertise, particularly with young people, which led him to establish this particular business. It seems to me that he is someone, with his experience of employing two people, who can impart to me as his federal member some of the difficulties, some of the challenges and some of the issues that he faces as an employer of two individuals. Of course, as an employer, he is giving a livelihood to two families, and it is very important that we listen to someone like him in terms of his small business. Someone else who is involved in the committee is Kay Gallagher. She runs The Gap Village News as well as a newsagency and comes into contact with many members of the community. She has all the credentials to be someone that can inform her federal member about the issues that come before her. I am delighted to be able to support small businesses in Ryan and assure them that they have my full support in promoting the issues that come before them into the national parliament. I look forward to working with them very closely to develop good solutions for their businesses. (Time expired) Chisholm Electorate: Box Hill North Primary School Ms BURKE (Chisholm) (11.15 a.m.)-I rise today to put in the Hansard some words from some remarkable people in my electorate-the year 5 and 6 literacy group from Box Hill North Primary School. Assistant principal and teacher, Miss Saitlik, writes: We hope that you as our Honourable Member of Federal Parliament may be able to relay these thoughts to the powers that be, simply to heighten their awareness that the young citizens of Australia have grave concerns and fears for others who share their world. Enclosed are letters from my students and additional information that will hopefully allow you to further your understanding of the significant contributions that our leaders of the future feel they can make in assisting the plights of those less fortunate than themselves. I will read the letters because I think they speak volumes. Sadly, I cannot read them all. Thursday, 22 August 2002 MAIN COMMITTEE 5553 Dear Anna, At the beginning of this year we researched Afghanistan. But it was not until we watched a BBC documentary called The Silent Scream that we realised how Afghanistan has been torn apart by war and corruption. The documentary was about Afghan women and how their rights had been taken away from them. We felt great pain for Afghan women when we saw footage of them being beaten and humiliated in the streets. We were even more distraught when we were shown an execution of a woman who was accused of murdering her husband, yet she was only accused of it. She had been living in a small rundown prison cell with two children. She was killed in a stadium, men filed in by the dozen to watch. But as she lay dead on the ground they simply walked out showing no emotion as if it was no more than a movie. This just isn’t right. It is inhumane and unjust. We felt angry, angry that our country has turned away people in such helpless situations. So what that they did not become legal refugees, most of the people sold their homes and most of their possessions to come to Australia under the impression that they would be welcome and kept safe, but instead they have either been turned away and sent somewhere else like unwanted luggage, or sent to detention centres which are by no means any different from what they were living in. They have been insulted by their own religions, so what do they do? What do they believe in now? Is there anything left to believe in? We hope that you will take what we have said into consideration. We may only be twelve year olds, but we are entitled to our opinions and we are not the only ones who feel this way. Yours sincerely, Eleanor Simcoe, Kimberley Phillips and Erin Marsicovetere. Dear Anna, We are writing to you to inform you of the abuse of Afghan women. Recently we have been researching Afghanistan and have uncovered the harsh life of women in Afghanistan. A BBC documentary called The Silent Scream really made us feel angry. It is heart wrenching to think that Afghani women can be treated so awfully. The women in Afghanistan are treated like flies. They are beaten. They are some sort of life size punching bag. They are accused of crimes that they didn’t even commit. The Northern Alliance told them they could take off their burquas but only the bravest women do. In Afghanistan animals are treated with more respect and dignity than women. Some of the women follow the Muslim religion and in believing in that religion they get beaten. They get beaten for the tiniest things. They get beaten for not being with men, they get imprisoned for wearing bell bottom trousers. To add to that, would it be so hard to let the Afghanistan women in detention centres become Australian citizens? As the young girl said in the detention centre, ‘You send us back to Afghanistan, you send us back to die!’ We hope you thoroughly read this letter and get it as far as you can to John Howard. From Jaydie and Anita Dear Anna, Yesterday in Literacy our teacher put on a BBC documentary. She warned us before we saw it that it was cruel and harsh but that does not even start to describe it. The documentary includes scenes of starving women, beggars and widows. The documentary was about Afghan women. Some of the scenes were taken from hidden cameras underneath women’s burquas, and were not light hearted. We have a question for you. How come when some women in Afghanistan who finally escape the torture and seek help in our country are turned down by the government, when towns are advertising land and jobs and need people? Recently, we have been researching all different areas of Afghanistan and we read a book called Parvana. Parvana was a girl who had to pretend to be a male and dig up bones just for a job, and that was before her father was imprisoned. The book didn’t have a happy ending as most books do. This was partly what inspired us to write to you. How heartless would you be to walk into a town, shoot all the men then just leave like nothing happened? This is why we feel so strongly about this topic. Please reply. Yours sincerely, Julia Kathro and Courtney Spreen. These letters go on and on, and I will read from the last one: Dear Anna, At the start of this year our literacy group looked into and researched everything including Afghanistan. To accompany our research, we read a book called ‘Parvana’, the story of an 11 year old girl, struggling to survive all the day to day battles of living in Afghanistan. We also watched 2 documentaries called ‘Tales from a Suitcase’. They were interviews of Afghan people who moved to Australia and how they got through it all. 5554 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 August 2002 As I say, these letters go on and on, and they are absolutely heartwrenching. It is just so beautiful that the students of our country can grasp the torture that these people have gone through-but our government cannot. Paterson Electorate: Hospitals in my electorate of Paterson. That issue is the need for a public hospital in Forster-Tuncurry, which is at the northern end of my electorate. At the end of July, a newspaper in the ForsterTuncurry region called the Great Lakes Advocate published a very interesting story. The front page had the headline, ‘Grey power grows-NSW’s oldest median age’. The story gave details of the median age of local government areas according to the 2001 census, and the Forster-Tuncurry district had the highest. The census found that the median age for the Great Lakes area was 47.3. This is the highest median age of any local government area in New South Wales. It also showed the increase in population from previous census figures. In 1996, the population in Great Lakes was 28,722. In 2001, at the time of the census, the population had risen by 2.6 per cent from the 1996 figure to 32,598 people. What these figures also reveal is the need to plan for the future and the lack of planning for health needs in this area. Clearly, the evidence is there to say the Great Lakes area is a growing area, with many pensioners and self-funded retirees moving into the region. And why wouldn’t they? The Great Lakes area is one of the most beautiful areas in the nation. But one of the problems facing the region is the need for a public hospital in the Forster-Tuncurry area. Residents currently have access to private hospital facilities at Forster, at the Cape Hawke Community Private Hospital. I need to inform the House that this is an outstanding facility which provides a high quality of care for its patients. But, for residents without private cover, many are finding the trip to the public hospital extremely difficult because the closest public hospital to Forster-Tuncurry is the Manning Base Hospital in Taree, some 50 kilometres away. For some, without a car or a partner to drive them to the hospital, the journey to Taree can be a long, frustrating and expensive exercise. It is an issue, just like the need for 24-hour policing in the town, which will gain momentum in the lead-up to the New South Wales election in March next year. And, with the responsibility for setting up hospitals, it is an issue that the state government cannot ignore. With a growing ageing population, it is clear that the New South Wales government must start planning for the future in this area. They must start providing some funds outside of the Sydney area and to this coastal region, where the funds are needed. These census figures are a blueprint for how the area is growing demographically and how government needs to start spending to cater for services in the future. Failing to recognise these important needs in the local community will cause extreme hardship to elderly Australians, who have paid their taxes throughout their working life and deserve quality care that is affordable. Planning for the future is good government. The New South Wales government must look at these census statistics and carefully plan for the health needs of the Great Lakes area, including provision for public hospital services. One option that has been put to me by a member of the community is whether the state government can lease beds from the Cape Hawke Community Private Hospital. This position is not being rejected by the hospital, but the state government seems reluctant to embrace it. Although this is not a long-term solution, it may help those in Forster-Tuncurry who have difficulty travelling to Manning Base Hospital. The point, though, is that the future health needs of the area must be seriously looked at by all levels of government to make sure the provision of services is fair and affordable.

speaker: Mr Baldwin (Paterson) (11.20 A.m.)
theText: I rise today to speak on an important health issueThursday, 22 August 2002 MAIN COMMITTEE 5555 I also take this opportunity to congratulate the volunteers who raise money for the palliative care unit at the Cape Hawke Community Private Hospital, known as Laurel Cottage. This unit provides great services to the local community because there is no public hospital and the unit is funded entirely by community donations. Since the unit first started over 12 years ago, volunteers have raised over $450,000. Every year they hold events such as movie screenings or fashion parades to raise the $40,000 to keep the unit going. There have been many volunteers who have generously given their time to this cause, and I would like to make special mention of the president of the group, Elizabeth Fisher, and Elizabeth Clarke, Robin Fisher and Frank Pushee on their achievements. Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, why is it that the things that are most important to us in life are funded by fetes and community fundraising rather than by governments? Aviation: Essendon Airport fringe of my electorate, has for some decades now been a quite controversial topic, largely because of perceptions in the local community of conflict between the residential character of the area and aviation operations. That is evidenced by a number of fatal accidents and tragedies over that time. Nonetheless, despite the residential concerns, the government has over recent times agreed to continue, at a diminished level, the aviation operations at the airport and has negotiated with a consortium involving Linfox and Becton to operate the airport. There are some positive features in those proposals in that the consortium obviously has a very strong commercial interest in intensifying commercial activity and development and hence jobs on the site, so this particular part of Melbourne is likely to benefit from that. However, there are serious problems in that process, the most notable problem being the exacerbation of very difficult traffic conditions, particularly at the interchange next to the airport between the Tullamarine Freeway leading on to City Link and the Calder Highway at that point. Already anyone who travels into Melbourne or out of Melbourne, particularly at peak hour, through that area knows just how difficult those traffic conditions are-and it is at the edge of a growing part of Melbourne. Intensification of activity associated with Essendon airport is going to really make that problem increasingly difficult. Regrettably, the Commonwealth government, in the process of negotiating management arrangements at the airport, has not done the very obvious thing of excising a portion of the airport land to enable improvement of the interchange at that point. It seems to me fairly negligent not to have done that, because there have been plans around for some considerable time to improve that interchange involving, as it would, the taking of some of the airport’s land, but it has not happened. It seems that a very essential step now for the Commonwealth to take is to recognise work needed at that interchange as being part of the Commonwealth program for roads of national importance. The Calder Freeway, as my colleague the member for Burke would be only too well aware, is recognised as a road of national importance and considerable work continues further north and west of Melbourne along that highway. But, at the end of the highway, where the highway reaches the Tullamarine Freeway and ceases to exist as a main road, it is absolute traffic chaos. Frankly, there is a need for the Commonwealth to recognise its need, in partnership with the Victorian government, to sort out the mess, particularly as its policies in relation to the development of Essendon airport are going to make the issue even more important. The state government talks about a figure of some $250 million being required to rebuild the interchange. WhilstI am not an engineer and would not want to second-guess engineering estimates, that seems to me to be very much at the upper end of what one could reasonably

speaker: Mr Sercombe (Maribyrnong) (11.25 A.m.)
theText: The Essendon airport, which is at the5556 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 August 2002 expect. Land acquisition costs, which are presumably built into that, ought to be minimised because it ought to be possible for the Commonwealth and the state to negotiate a satisfactory arrangement with the airport operator because the airport operator will substantially benefit from improvement of the traffic conditions around the site. Frankly, the configuration of the airport and the roads into it at the moment are a bit of a mess, but, by some basic clever design, it may be possible for the airport operator to get a substantially better utilisation of parts of the sites which are presently landlocked by some effective design. I would expect land acquisition costs associated with road improvements would dramatically reduce that $250 million estimate and, in fact, depending upon the route across the airport that was agreed, it may be possible to significantly reduce construction costs as well. In this situation, whilst the local community undoubtedly loses through the Commonwealth’s determination to continue aviation activities at Essendon Airport, everyone expects that those aviation activities will significantly diminish over future years. With that caveat, a win-win-win situation is possible: a win for the Commonwealth in terms of getting much better access to what is Australia’s largest curfew free airport, Melbourne airport, by road improvements; a win for the operator of the airport in getting a better result; and a win for the local community in solving the very substantial problem of traffic congestion. (Time expired) Dunkley Electorate: Mature Age Unemployment occurring in the Dunkley electorate. A number of key stakeholders, training providers, participants in a Job Network program and I are putting together a project called the Mature Aged Career Collaboration. It is aimed at assisting and supporting local unemployed people who are over the age of 45. We know that economic and social drivers will, over time, increasingly promote mature age employment. However, more immediate action is required to ensure that the talent and capacity of the current mature age job seeker is not lost to the economy and to abate the significant personal costs of their joblessness. In 1976, Australia had 1.3 million people over the age of 65, which represented nine per cent of the total population. In March last year, there were 2.3 million people over the age of 65, or 12 per cent of the population. By 2016, there will be 3½ million people over the age of 65, representing 16 per cent of the total population. That will rise to 6.03 million by the middle of this century, meaning that 25 per cent of our entire population will be over the age of 65. Work is a key defining element of an individual’s character. As the Nelson committee recognised in its Age Counts report in the year 2000: Work puts us in a social context, defines the framework of our lives and gives each of us a sense of belonging and meaningful purpose. Being without a job not only devastates personal finances but also exacts a heavy social and human toll. In 1997, the ABS reported that nearly half of all men over the age of 45 were out of the workplace through retrenchment, redundancy or retirement. The unemployment rate for mature age people is lower than that for the general population, but the rate of long-term unemployment is much higher. This represents what the Nelson committee described as ‘the tip of an iceberg of quiet anguish’. Access Economics reported at the start of last year that the working age population currently grows by about 170,000 people but that, if current population trends continue, by the year 2020 the entire working age population will grow by just 125,000 people for the whole decade. Clearly, we need to be cleverer, smarter and more engaged as a nation in ensuring that mature age people are able to fully participate in the workplace.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Billson (Dunkley) (11.30 A.m.)
theText: I rise today to talk about an exciting collaborationThursday, 22 August 2002 MAIN COMMITTEE 5557 In Dunkley, we are bringing the players together to try to support the re-employment and re-engagement of mature age job seekers. We have found that, in addition to tackling the unjustified bias that many employers have against employing a mature age person, there are things we can do to work with, to support and to encourage the mature age job seeker. Computer literacy is increasingly recognised as a core competency without which it is very difficult to gain employment. We are putting in place an IT skills program for job seekers so that they can display a level of computer competency, or at least the absence of fear of computer technology, to prospective employers. In terms of positivity and self-confidence, there is the need to project an engaging character that is worthy and valued in the workplace. Also, the labour market has changed. Some mature age job seekers have not sought employment in the workplace for about 20 years and find that the tactics, the choices and the opportunities that were appropriate 20 years ago are now not part of the labour market. The last issue, which is the most important one, in my view, is the concept of workplace mobility. A lot of people who have worked in traditional areas of employment only see work opportunities in that area, whereas the skills and competencies they have are quite transferable. We will be working with those job seekers to recognise their abilities and to make sure that they are fully engaged in the workplace. Tzvi Lachman and Melody Rewakowski are working with us, and they have done a lot of good work in the state of Oregon. We also have Your Employment Solutions and Barry Smith helping us. SkillsPlus Peninsula are helping with the training venue, IT capacity and the mentoring that is needed for these mature age job seekers.
